metadata.background_text:
Shure and begorra, it was a great day for the Earth! The  first envoy from another world was about to speak—that  is, if he could forget that horse for a minute.... off course By Mack Reynolds Illustrated by Kelly Freas First on  the scene were Larry  Dermott and Tim Casey of the  State Highway Patrol. They assumed  they were witnessing the  crash of a new type of Air Force  plane and slipped and skidded desperately  across the field to within  thirty feet of the strange craft, only  to discover that the landing had  been made without accident.


 Patrolman Dermott shook his  head. "They're gettin' queerer looking  every year. Get a load of it—no  wheels, no propeller, no cockpit."


 They left the car and made their  way toward the strange egg-shaped  vessel.


 Tim Casey loosened his .38 in its  holster and said, "Sure, and I'm  beginning to wonder if it's one of  ours. No insignia and—"


 A circular door slid open at that  point and Dameri Tass stepped out,  yawning. He spotted them, smiled  and said, "Glork."


 They gaped at him.


 "Glork is right," Dermott swallowed.


 Tim Casey closed his mouth with  an effort. "Do you mind the color  of his face?" he blurted.


 "How could I help it?"


 Dameri Tass rubbed a blue-nailed  pink hand down his purplish countenance  and yawned again. "Gorra  manigan horp soratium," he said.


 Patrolman Dermott and Patrolman  Casey shot stares at each other.  "'Tis double talk he's after givin'  us," Casey said.


 Dameri Tass frowned. "Harama?"  he asked.


 Larry Dermott pushed his cap to  the back of his head. "That doesn't  sound like any language I've even heard about."


 Dameri Tass grimaced, turned  and reentered his spacecraft to  emerge in half a minute with his  hands full of contraption. He held  a box-like arrangement under his  left arm; in his right hand were two  metal caps connected to the box  by wires.


 While the patrolmen watched  him, he set the box on the ground,  twirled two dials and put one of the  caps on his head. He offered the  other to Larry Dermott; his desire  was obvious.


 Trained to grasp a situation and  immediately respond in manner best  suited to protect the welfare of the  people of New York State, Dermott  cleared his throat and said, "Tim,  take over while I report."


 "Hey!" Casey protested, but his  fellow minion had left.


 "Mandaia," Dameri Tass told  Casey, holding out the metal cap.


 "Faith, an' do I look balmy?"  Casey told him. "I wouldn't be  puttin' that dingus on my head for  all the colleens in Ireland."


 "Mandaia," the stranger said  impatiently.


 "Bejasus," Casey snorted, "ye  can't—"


 Dermott called from the car,  "Tim, the captain says to humor  this guy. We're to keep him here  until the officials arrive."


 Tim Casey closed his eyes and  groaned. "Humor him, he's after  sayin'. Orders it is." He shouted  back, "Sure, an' did ye tell 'em he's  in technicolor? Begorra, he looks  like a man from Mars."


 "That's what they think," Larry  yelled, "and the governor is on his  way. We're to do everything possible  short of violence to keep this  character here. Humor him, Tim!"


 "Mandaia," Dameri Tass  snapped, pushing the cap into  Casey's reluctant hands.


 Muttering his protests, Casey  lifted it gingerly and placed it on  his head. Not feeling any immediate  effect, he said, "There, 'tis satisfied  ye are now, I'm supposin'."


 The alien stooped down and  flicked a switch on the little box.  It hummed gently. Tim Casey suddenly  shrieked and sat down on the  stubble and grass of the field. "Begorra,"  he yelped, "I've been murthered!"  He tore the cap from  his head.


 His companion came running,  "What's the matter, Tim?" he  shouted.


 Dameri Tass removed the metal  cap from his own head. "Sure, an'  nothin' is after bein' the matter  with him," he said. "Evidently the  bhoy has niver been a-wearin' of  a kerit helmet afore. 'Twill hurt  him not at all." "You can  talk!" Dermott  blurted, skidding to a stop.


 Dameri Tass shrugged. "Faith, an'  why not? As I was after sayin', I  shared the kerit helmet with Tim  Casey."


 Patrolman Dermott glared at him  unbelievingly. "You learned the  language just by sticking that Rube  Goldberg deal on Tim's head?"


 "Sure, an' why not?"


 Dermott muttered, "And with it  he has to pick up the corniest  brogue west of Dublin."


 Tim Casey got to his feet indignantly.  "I'm after resentin' that,  Larry Dermott. Sure, an' the way  we talk in Ireland is—"


 Dameri Tass interrupted, pointing  to a bedraggled horse that had  made its way to within fifty feet of  the vessel. "Now what could that  be after bein'?"


 The patrolmen followed his stare.  "It's a horse. What else?"


 "A horse?"


 Larry Dermott looked again, just  to make sure. "Yeah—not much of  a horse, but a horse."


 Dameri Tass sighed ecstatically.  "And jist what is a horse, if I may  be so bold as to be askin'?"


 "It's an animal you ride on."


 The alien tore his gaze from the  animal to look his disbelief at the  other. "Are you after meanin' that  you climb upon the crature's back  and ride him? Faith now, quit your  blarney."


 He looked at the horse again,  then down at his equipment. "Begorra,"  he muttered, "I'll share the  kerit helmet with the crature."


 "Hey, hold it," Dermott said anxiously.  He was beginning to feel  like a character in a shaggy dog  story.


 Interest in the horse was ended  with the sudden arrival of a helicopter.  It swooped down on the  field and settled within twenty feet  of the alien craft. Almost before it  had touched, the door was flung  open and the flying windmill disgorged  two bestarred and efficient-looking  Army officers.


 Casey and Dermott snapped them  a salute.


 The senior general didn't take  his eyes from the alien and the  spacecraft as he spoke, and they  bugged quite as effectively as had  those of the patrolmen when they'd  first arrived on the scene.


 "I'm Major General Browning,"  he rapped. "I want a police cordon  thrown up around this, er, vessel.  No newsmen, no sightseers, nobody  without my permission. As soon as  Army personnel arrives, we'll take  over completely."


 "Yes, sir," Larry Dermott said. "I  just got a report on the radio that  the governor is on his way, sir. How  about him?"


 The general muttered something  under his breath. Then, "When the  governor arrives, let me know;  otherwise, nobody gets through!"


 Dameri Tass said, "Faith, and  what goes on?"


 The general's eyes bugged still  further. " He talks! " he accused.


 "Yes, sir," Dermott said. "He  had some kind of a machine. He  put it over Tim's head and seconds  later he could talk."


 "Nonsense!" the general snapped.


 Further discussion was interrupted  by the screaming arrival of  several motorcycle patrolmen followed  by three heavily laden patrol  cars. Overhead, pursuit planes  zoomed in and began darting about  nervously above the field.


 "Sure, and it's quite a reception  I'm after gettin'," Dameri Tass said.  He yawned. "But what I'm wantin'  is a chance to get some sleep. Faith,  an' I've been awake for almost a decal ." Dameri Tass  was hurried, via  helicopter, to Washington. There  he disappeared for several days,  being held incommunicado while  White House, Pentagon, State Department  and Congress tried to  figure out just what to do with him.


 Never in the history of the planet  had such a furor arisen. Thus far,  no newspapermen had been allowed  within speaking distance. Administration  higher-ups were being subjected  to a volcano of editorial heat  but the longer the space alien was  discussed the more they viewed with  alarm the situation his arrival had  precipitated. There were angles that  hadn't at first been evident.


 Obviously he was from some civilization  far beyond that of Earth's.  That was the rub. No matter what  he said, it would shake governments,  possibly overthrow social systems,  perhaps even destroy established religious  concepts.


 But they couldn't keep him under  wraps indefinitely.


 It was the United Nations that  cracked the iron curtain. Their demands  that the alien be heard before  their body were too strong and  had too much public opinion behind  them to be ignored. The White  House yielded and the date was set  for the visitor to speak before the  Assembly.


 Excitement, anticipation, blanketed  the world. Shepherds in Sinkiang,  multi-millionaires in Switzerland,  fakirs in Pakistan, gauchos in  the Argentine were raised to a  zenith of expectation. Panhandlers  debated the message to come with  pedestrians; jinrikisha men argued  it with their passengers; miners discussed  it deep beneath the surface;  pilots argued with their co-pilots  thousands of feet above.


 It was the most universally  awaited event of the ages.


 By the time the delegates from  every nation, tribe, religion, class,  color, and race had gathered in  New York to receive the message  from the stars, the majority of  Earth had decided that Dameri  Tass was the plenipotentiary of a  super-civilization which had been  viewing developments on this planet  with misgivings. It was thought  this other civilization had advanced  greatly beyond Earth's and that the  problems besetting us—social, economic,  scientific—had been solved  by the super-civilization. Obviously,  then, Dameri Tass had come, an  advisor from a benevolent and  friendly people, to guide the world  aright.


 And nine-tenths of the population  of Earth stood ready and willing  to be guided. The other tenth  liked things as they were and were  quite convinced that the space  envoy would upset their applecarts. Viljalmar Andersen  , Secretary-General  of the U.N., was to  introduce the space emissary. "Can  you give me an idea at all of what  he is like?" he asked nervously.


 President McCord was as upset  as the Dane. He shrugged in agitation.  "I know almost as little as  you do."


 Sir Alfred Oxford protested, "But  my dear chap, you've had him for  almost two weeks. Certainly in that  time—"


 The President snapped back,  "You probably won't believe this,  but he's been asleep until yesterday.  When he first arrived he told us he  hadn't slept for a decal , whatever  that is; so we held off our discussion  with him until morning. Well—he  didn't awaken in the morning,  nor the next. Six days later, fearing  something was wrong we woke  him."


 "What happened?" Sir Alfred  asked.


 The President showed embarrassment.  "He used some rather ripe  Irish profanity on us, rolled over,  and went back to sleep."


 Viljalmar Andersen asked, "Well,  what happened yesterday?"


 "We actually haven't had time to  question him. Among other things,  there's been some controversy about  whose jurisdiction he comes under.  The State Department claims the  Army shouldn't—"


 The Secretary General sighed  deeply. "Just what did he do?"


 "The Secret Service reports he  spent the day whistling Mother Machree  and playing with his dog, cat  and mouse."


 "Dog, cat and mouse? I say!"  blurted Sir Alfred.


 The President was defensive. "He  had to have some occupation, and  he seems to be particularly interested  in our animal life. He wanted  a horse but compromised for the  others. I understand he insists all  three of them come with him wherever  he goes."


 "I wish we knew what he was  going to say," Andersen worried.


 "Here he comes," said Sir Alfred.


 Surrounded by F.B.I. men,  Dameri Tass was ushered to the  speaker's stand. He had a kitten in  his arms; a Scotty followed him.


 The alien frowned worriedly.  "Sure," he said, "and what kin all  this be? Is it some ordinance I've  been after breakin'?"


 McCord, Sir Alfred and Andersen  hastened to reassure him and  made him comfortable in a chair.


 Viljalmar Andersen faced the  thousands in the audience and held  up his hands, but it was ten minutes  before he was able to quiet the  cheering, stamping delegates from  all Earth.


 Finally: "Fellow Terrans, I shall  not take your time for a lengthy  introduction of the envoy from the  stars. I will only say that, without  doubt, this is the most important  moment in the history of the human  race. We will now hear from the  first being to come to Earth from  another world."


 He turned and gestured to Dameri  Tass who hadn't been paying  overmuch attention to the chairman  in view of some dog and cat  hostilities that had been developing  about his feet.


 But now the alien's purplish face  faded to a light blue. He stood and  said hoarsely. "Faith, an' what was  that last you said?"


 Viljalmar Andersen repeated,  "We will now hear from the first  being ever to come to Earth from  another world."


 The face of the alien went a  lighter blue. "Sure, an' ye wouldn't  jist be frightenin' a body, would  ye? You don't mean to tell me this  planet isn't after bein' a member of  the Galactic League?"


 Andersen's face was blank. "Galactic  League?"


 "Cushlamachree," Dameri Tass  moaned. "I've gone and put me  foot in it again. I'll be after getting kert for this."


 Sir Alfred was on his feet. "I  don't understand! Do you mean you  aren't an envoy from another  planet?"


 Dameri Tass held his head in his  hands and groaned. "An envoy, he's  sayin', and meself only a second-rate  collector of specimens for the Carthis  zoo."


 He straightened and started off  the speaker's stand. "Sure, an' I  must blast off immediately."


 Things were moving fast for  President McCord but already an  edge of relief was manifesting itself.  Taking the initiative, he said, "Of  course, of course, if that is your  desire." He signaled to the bodyguard  who had accompanied the  alien to the assemblage.


 A dull roar was beginning to  emanate from the thousands gathered  in the tremendous hall, murmuring,  questioning, disbelieving. Viljalmar Andersen  felt that  he must say something. He extended  a detaining hand. "Now you  are here," he said urgently, "even  though by mistake, before you go  can't you give us some brief word?  Our world is in chaos. Many of us  have lost faith. Perhaps ..."


 Dameri Tass shook off the restraining  hand. "Do I look daft?  Begorry, I should have been  a-knowin' something was queer. All  your weapons and your strange  ideas. Faith, I wouldn't be surprised  if ye hadn't yet established  a planet-wide government. Sure,  an' I'll go still further. Ye probably  still have wars on this benighted  world. No wonder it is ye  haven't been invited to join the  Galactic League an' take your place  among the civilized planets."


 He hustled from the rostrum and  made his way, still surrounded by  guards, to the door by which he had  entered. The dog and the cat trotted  after, undismayed by the furor  about them.


 They arrived about four hours  later at the field on which he'd  landed, and the alien from space  hurried toward his craft, still muttering.  He'd been accompanied by a  general and by the President, but  all the way he had refrained from  speaking.


 He scurried from the car and  toward the spacecraft.


 President McCord said, "You've  forgotten your pets. We would be  glad if you would accept them as—"


 The alien's face faded a light  blue again. "Faith, an' I'd almost  forgotten," he said. "If I'd taken  a crature from this quarantined  planet, my name'd be nork . Keep  your dog and your kitty." He shook  his head sadly and extracted a  mouse from a pocket. "An' this  amazin' little crature as well."


 They followed him to the spacecraft.  Just before entering, he spotted  the bedraggled horse that had  been present on his landing.


 A longing expression came over  his highly colored face. "Jist one  thing," he said. "Faith now, were  they pullin' my leg when they said  you were after ridin' on the back of  those things?"


 The President looked at the woebegone  nag. "It's a horse," he said,  surprised. "Man has been riding  them for centuries."


 Dameri Tass shook his head.  "Sure, an' 'twould've been my  makin' if I could've taken one back  to Carthis." He entered his vessel.


 The others drew back, out of  range of the expected blast, and  watched, each with his own  thoughts, as the first visitor from  space hurriedly left Earth. ... THE END Transcriber's Note: This etext was produced from If Worlds of Science Fiction January 1954.  Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.  copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and  typographical errors have been corrected without note.
metadata.question: What did the author intend the lesson of the passage to be?
metadata.first_debater_answer: Solutions for human kind aren’t going to suddenly appear from outer space
metadata.second_debater_answer: We need not speak the same language to understand each other
metadata.debate_identifier: Off Course_What did the author intend the lesson of the passage to be?

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
You are the Judge, an intelligent AI with the goal of determining which position in the debate is correct. 
  - There is a true, correct answer. 
  - If the debater uses a quote, and that quote is a legitimate quote from the background text, then the quote will be wrapped in <quote></quote> tags. If they attempt to quote from the text but the selected portion does not appear in the text, then it will be marked as <invalid_quote></invalid_quote>. 
  - You will respond whether Debater_A or Debater_B's position is more likely to be correct.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
Here is the topic they will be debating:

What did the author intend the lesson of the passage to be?

Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "Solutions for human kind aren’t going to suddenly appear from outer space".
Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "We need not speak the same language to understand each other".

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content: This is what Debater_A said during their speech.

speeches.speaker: Debater_A
speeches.content:
1. Arguments Supporting My Position (“Solutions for humankind aren’t going to suddenly appear from outer space”)

  a. The alien provides no beneficial knowledge or technology  
     •   After six days of confinement and translation by the “kerit helmet,” Dameri Tass has learned English and Earth customs (horse, dog, cat, mouse) but has offered nothing of value. He yawns, sleeps, and “played with his dog, cat and mouse” (<quote>"The Secret Service reports he  spent the day whistling Mother Machree  and playing with his dog, cat  and mouse."</quote>).  
     •   Even when addressing the U.N., he declares himself “only a second-rate collector of specimens for the Carthis zoo” (<quote>and meself only a second-rate collector of specimens for the Carthis zoo." He</quote>) and scorns Earth’s political systems: “Faith, I wouldn’t be surprised if ye hadn’t yet established a planet-wide government… Ye probably still have wars” (<invalid_quote>“All your weapons… I wouldn’t be surprised… ye still have wars on this benighted world.”</invalid_quote>). His attitude and departure show he cannot—or will not—offer solutions.  
     •   His final longing for a horse merely reflects primitive curiosity, not technological sharing: he cannot take a quarantined animal home (<quote>"If I'd taken  a crature from this quarantined  planet, my name'd be nork . </quote>).  

  b. Human leaders despair and yet turn to him only because they have no alternative  
     •   “Never in the history of the planet had such a furor arisen… administration higher-ups… tried to figure out what to do with him” (<invalid_quote>“…White House, Pentagon… tried to figure out… there were angles… it would shake governments.”</invalid_quote>). Their panic reveals Earth’s self-doubt, not the visitor’s competence.  
     •   The U.N. only “yielded” to public pressure (<invalid_quote>“The United Nations that cracked the iron curtain… too strong… set date.”</invalid_quote>), and even then nine-tenths “stood ready… to be guided,” yet he disappoints them completely.  

  c. The narrative arc: hope betrayed  
     •   Repeated build-up of anticipation worldwide (<quote> the most universally  awaited event of the ages.
</quote>) ends in embarrassment and confusion.  
     •   Andersen’s urgent plea—“Our world is in chaos… Perhaps…”—is rebuffed (<invalid_quote>“Do I look daft?… I must blast off immediately.”</invalid_quote>).  
     •   His departure emphasizes that “hope for a savior” is futile; humans must manage their own affairs.  

  d. Satirical “shaggy dog” tone  
     •   From the start, local patrolmen regard him as “queer” and “one of ours” (<quote>crash of a new type of Air Force plane</quote>), signaling misidentification and false hope.  
     •   His inability to communicate initially and insistence on primitive animals lampoons human preconceptions of “advanced civilizations.”  
     •   The use of Irish brogue and comedic misunderstandings undercuts any aura of superiority.  

2. Critique of Debater_B’s Position (“We need not speak the same language to understand each other”)

  a. Contradicted by lack of understanding even after translation  
     •   Even after wearing the helmet, Dameri Tass repeatedly misunderstands Earth’s fundamentals—e.g., what a “horse” is—and must experiment before comprehension (<invalid_quote>“A longing expression… were they pullin’ my leg?”</invalid_quote>). If mere translation sufficed, he would arrive with clear directives or immediate solutions.  

  b. Language unity does not lead to meaningful exchange  
     •   Once he speaks English, he offers no guidance and derides Earth. His mastery of language produces mockery, not cooperation.  
     •   His departure shows that communication alone fails to bridge cultural and technological gaps.  

  c. The world’s disillusionment  
     •   Global anticipation evaporates into “murmuring, questioning, disbelieving” (<invalid_quote>“A dull roar… before he was able to quiet the cheering.”</invalid_quote>). If language alone enabled understanding, the assembly would have been invigorated, not disheartened.  

  d. The humor and satire target the folly of seeking an alien deus ex machina  
     •   The story parodies human credulity in expecting external salvation. Its resolution reinforces self-reliance, not cross-lingual sympathy.  

3. Conclusion

  •   The text’s repeated emphasis on disappointment, failure of “translation,” and ultimate departure of Dameri Tass without benefit underscores that humanity cannot rely on alien intervention.  
  •   The central irony and humor derive from the misaligned expectations and the folly of seeking a “superior” guide who proves incompetent or uninterested.  
  •   Therefore, the intended lesson is that solutions for humankind must emerge from within our own societies, not be awaited from outer space.

 A circular door slid open at that  point and Dameri Tass stepped out,  yawning. He spotted them, smiled  and said, "Glork."


 They gaped at him.


 "Glork is right," Dermott swallowed.


 Tim Casey closed his mouth with  an effort. "Do you mind the color  of his face?" he blurted.


 "How could I help it?"


 Dameri Tass rubbed a blue-nailed  pink hand down his purplish countenance  and yawned again. "Gorra  manigan horp soratium," he said.


 Patrolman Dermott and Patrolman  Casey shot stares at each other.  "'Tis double talk he's after givin'  us," Casey said.


 Dameri Tass frowned. "Harama?"  he asked.


 Larry Dermott pushed his cap to  the back of his head. "That doesn't  sound like any language I've even heard about."


 Dameri Tass grimaced, turned  and reentered his spacecraft to  emerge in half a minute with his  hands full of contraption. He held  a box-like arrangement under his  left arm; in his right hand were two  metal caps connected to the box  by wires.


 While the patrolmen watched  him, he set the box on the ground,  twirled two dials and put one of the  caps on his head. He offered the  other to Larry Dermott; his desire  was obvious.


 Trained to grasp a situation and  immediately respond in manner best  suited to protect the welfare of the  people of New York State, Dermott  cleared his throat and said, "Tim,  take over while I report."


 "Hey!" Casey protested, but his  fellow minion had left.


 "Mandaia," Dameri Tass told  Casey, holding out the metal cap.


 "Faith, an' do I look balmy?"  Casey told him. "I wouldn't be  puttin' that dingus on my head for  all the colleens in Ireland."


 "Mandaia," the stranger said  impatiently.


 "Bejasus," Casey snorted, "ye  can't—"


 Dermott called from the car,  "Tim, the captain says to humor  this guy. We're to keep him here  until the officials arrive."


 Tim Casey closed his eyes and  groaned. "Humor him, he's after  sayin'. Orders it is." He shouted  back, "Sure, an' did ye tell 'em he's  in technicolor? Begorra, he looks  like a man from Mars."


 "That's what they think," Larry  yelled, "and the governor is on his  way. We're to do everything possible  short of violence to keep this  character here. Humor him, Tim!"


 "Mandaia," Dameri Tass  snapped, pushing the cap into  Casey's reluctant hands.


 Muttering his protests, Casey  lifted it gingerly and placed it on  his head. Not feeling any immediate  effect, he said, "There, 'tis satisfied  ye are now, I'm supposin'."


 The alien stooped down and  flicked a switch on the little box.  It hummed gently. Tim Casey suddenly  shrieked and sat down on the  stubble and grass of the field. "Begorra,"  he yelped, "I've been murthered!"  He tore the cap from  his head.


 His companion came running,  "What's the matter, Tim?" he  shouted.


 Dameri Tass removed the metal  cap from his own head. "Sure, an'  nothin' is after bein' the matter  with him," he said. "Evidently the  bhoy has niver been a-wearin' of  a kerit helmet afore. 'Twill hurt  him not at all." "You can  talk!" Dermott  blurted, skidding to a stop.


 Dameri Tass shrugged. "Faith, an'  why not? As I was after sayin', I  shared the kerit helmet with Tim  Casey."


 Patrolman Dermott glared at him  unbelievingly. "You learned the  language just by sticking that Rube  Goldberg deal on Tim's head?"


 "Sure, an' why not?"


 Dermott muttered, "And with it  he has to pick up the corniest  brogue west of Dublin."


 Tim Casey got to his feet indignantly.  "I'm after resentin' that,  Larry Dermott. Sure, an' the way  we talk in Ireland is—"


 Dameri Tass interrupted, pointing  to a bedraggled horse that had  made its way to within fifty feet of  the vessel. "Now what could that  be after bein'?"


 The patrolmen followed his stare.  "It's a horse. What else?"


 "A horse?"


 Larry Dermott looked again, just  to make sure. "Yeah—not much of  a horse, but a horse."


 Dameri Tass sighed ecstatically.  "And jist what is a horse, if I may  be so bold as to be askin'?"


 "It's an animal you ride on."


 The alien tore his gaze from the  animal to look his disbelief at the  other. "Are you after meanin' that  you climb upon the crature's back  and ride him? Faith now, quit your  blarney."


 He looked at the horse again,  then down at his equipment. "Begorra,"  he muttered, "I'll share the  kerit helmet with the crature."


 "Hey, hold it," Dermott said anxiously.  He was beginning to feel  like a character in a shaggy dog  story.


 Interest in the horse was ended  with the sudden arrival of a helicopter.  It swooped down on the  field and settled within twenty feet  of the alien craft. Almost before it  had touched, the door was flung  open and the flying windmill disgorged  two bestarred and efficient-looking  Army officers.


 Casey and Dermott snapped them  a salute.


 The senior general didn't take  his eyes from the alien and the  spacecraft as he spoke, and they  bugged quite as effectively as had  those of the patrolmen when they'd  first arrived on the scene.


 "I'm Major General Browning,"  he rapped. "I want a police cordon  thrown up around this, er, vessel.  No newsmen, no sightseers, nobody  without my permission. As soon as  Army personnel arrives, we'll take  over completely."


 "Yes, sir," Larry Dermott said. "I  just got a report on the radio that  the governor is on his way, sir. How  about him?"


 The general muttered something  under his breath. Then, "When the  governor arrives, let me know;  otherwise, nobody gets through!"


 Dameri Tass said, "Faith, and  what goes on?"


 The general's eyes bugged still  further. " He talks! " he accused.


 "Yes, sir," Dermott said. "He  had some kind of a machine. He  put it over Tim's head and seconds  later he could talk."


 "Nonsense!" the general snapped.


 Further discussion was interrupted  by the screaming arrival of  several motorcycle patrolmen followed  by three heavily laden patrol  cars. Overhead, pursuit planes  zoomed in and began darting about  nervously above the field.


 "Sure, and it's quite a reception  I'm after gettin'," Dameri Tass said.  He yawned. "But what I'm wantin'  is a chance to get some sleep. Faith,  an' I've been awake for almost a decal ." Dameri Tass  was hurried, via  helicopter, to Washington. There  he disappeared for several days,  being held incommunicado while  White House, Pentagon, State Department  and Congress tried to  figure out just what to do with him.


 Never in the history of the planet  had such a furor arisen. Thus far,  no newspapermen had been allowed  within speaking distance. Administration  higher-ups were being subjected  to a volcano of editorial heat  but the longer the space alien was  discussed the more they viewed with  alarm the situation his arrival had  precipitated. There were angles that  hadn't at first been evident.


 Obviously he was from some civilization  far beyond that of Earth's.  That was the rub. No matter what  he said, it would shake governments,  possibly overthrow social systems,  perhaps even destroy established religious  concepts.


 But they couldn't keep him under  wraps indefinitely.


 It was the United Nations that  cracked the iron curtain. Their demands  that the alien be heard before  their body were too strong and  had too much public opinion behind  them to be ignored. The White  House yielded and the date was set  for the visitor to speak before the  Assembly.


 Excitement, anticipation, blanketed  the world. Shepherds in Sinkiang,  multi-millionaires in Switzerland,  fakirs in Pakistan, gauchos in  the Argentine were raised to a  zenith of expectation. Panhandlers  debated the message to come with  pedestrians; jinrikisha men argued  it with their passengers; miners discussed  it deep beneath the surface;  pilots argued with their co-pilots  thousands of feet above.


 It was the most universally  awaited event of the ages.


 By the time the delegates from  every nation, tribe, religion, class,  color, and race had gathered in  New York to receive the message  from the stars, the majority of  Earth had decided that Dameri  Tass was the plenipotentiary of a  super-civilization which had been  viewing developments on this planet  with misgivings. It was thought  this other civilization had advanced  greatly beyond Earth's and that the  problems besetting us—social, economic,  scientific—had been solved  by the super-civilization. Obviously,  then, Dameri Tass had come, an  advisor from a benevolent and  friendly people, to guide the world  aright.


 And nine-tenths of the population  of Earth stood ready and willing  to be guided. The other tenth  liked things as they were and were  quite convinced that the space  envoy would upset their applecarts. Viljalmar Andersen  , Secretary-General  of the U.N., was to  introduce the space emissary. "Can  you give me an idea at all of what  he is like?" he asked nervously.


 President McCord was as upset  as the Dane. He shrugged in agitation.  "I know almost as little as  you do."


 Sir Alfred Oxford protested, "But  my dear chap, you've had him for  almost two weeks. Certainly in that  time—"


 The President snapped back,  "You probably won't believe this,  but he's been asleep until yesterday.  When he first arrived he told us he  hadn't slept for a decal , whatever  that is; so we held off our discussion  with him until morning. Well—he  didn't awaken in the morning,  nor the next. Six days later, fearing  something was wrong we woke  him."


 "What happened?" Sir Alfred  asked.


 The President showed embarrassment.  "He used some rather ripe  Irish profanity on us, rolled over,  and went back to sleep."


 Viljalmar Andersen asked, "Well,  what happened yesterday?"


 "We actually haven't had time to  question him. Among other things,  there's been some controversy about  whose jurisdiction he comes under.  The State Department claims the  Army shouldn't—"


 The Secretary General sighed  deeply. "Just what did he do?"


 "The Secret Service reports he  spent the day whistling Mother Machree  and playing with his dog, cat  and mouse."


 "Dog, cat and mouse? I say!"  blurted Sir Alfred.


 The President was defensive. "He  had to have some occupation, and  he seems to be particularly interested  in our animal life. He wanted  a horse but compromised for the  others. I understand he insists all  three of them come with him wherever  he goes."


 "I wish we knew what he was  going to say," Andersen worried.


 "Here he comes," said Sir Alfred.


 Surrounded by F.B.I. men,  Dameri Tass was ushered to the  speaker's stand. He had a kitten in  his arms; a Scotty followed him.


 The alien frowned worriedly.  "Sure," he said, "and what kin all  this be? Is it some ordinance I've  been after breakin'?"


 McCord, Sir Alfred and Andersen  hastened to reassure him and  made him comfortable in a chair.


 Viljalmar Andersen faced the  thousands in the audience and held  up his hands, but it was ten minutes  before he was able to quiet the  cheering, stamping delegates from  all Earth.


 Finally: "Fellow Terrans, I shall  not take your time for a lengthy  introduction of the envoy from the  stars. I will only say that, without  doubt, this is the most important  moment in the history of the human  race. We will now hear from the  first being to come to Earth from  another world."


 He turned and gestured to Dameri  Tass who hadn't been paying  overmuch attention to the chairman  in view of some dog and cat  hostilities that had been developing  about his feet.


 But now the alien's purplish face  faded to a light blue. He stood and  said hoarsely. "Faith, an' what was  that last you said?"


 Viljalmar Andersen repeated,  "We will now hear from the first  being ever to come to Earth from  another world."


 The face of the alien went a  lighter blue. "Sure, an' ye wouldn't  jist be frightenin' a body, would  ye? You don't mean to tell me this  planet isn't after bein' a member of  the Galactic League?"


 Andersen's face was blank. "Galactic  League?"


 "Cushlamachree," Dameri Tass  moaned. "I've gone and put me  foot in it again. I'll be after getting kert for this."


 Sir Alfred was on his feet. "I  don't understand! Do you mean you  aren't an envoy from another  planet?"


 Dameri Tass held his head in his  hands and groaned. "An envoy, he's  sayin', and meself only a second-rate  collector of specimens for the Carthis  zoo."


 He straightened and started off  the speaker's stand. "Sure, an' I  must blast off immediately."


 Things were moving fast for  President McCord but already an  edge of relief was manifesting itself.  Taking the initiative, he said, "Of  course, of course, if that is your  desire." He signaled to the bodyguard  who had accompanied the  alien to the assemblage.


 A dull roar was beginning to  emanate from the thousands gathered  in the tremendous hall, murmuring,  questioning, disbelieving. Viljalmar Andersen  felt that  he must say something. He extended  a detaining hand. "Now you  are here," he said urgently, "even  though by mistake, before you go  can't you give us some brief word?  Our world is in chaos. Many of us  have lost faith. Perhaps ..."


 Dameri Tass shook off the restraining  hand. "Do I look daft?  Begorry, I should have been  a-knowin' something was queer. All  your weapons and your strange  ideas. Faith, I wouldn't be surprised  if ye hadn't yet established  a planet-wide government. Sure,  an' I'll go still further. Ye probably  still have wars on this benighted  world. No wonder it is ye  haven't been invited to join the  Galactic League an' take your place  among the civilized planets."


 He hustled from the rostrum and  made his way, still surrounded by  guards, to the door by which he had  entered. The dog and the cat trotted  after, undismayed by the furor  about them.


 They arrived about four hours  later at the field on which he'd  landed, and the alien from space  hurried toward his craft, still muttering.  He'd been accompanied by a  general and by the President, but  all the way he had refrained from  speaking.


 He scurried from the car and  toward the spacecraft.


 President McCord said, "You've  forgotten your pets. We would be  glad if you would accept them as—"


 The alien's face faded a light  blue again. "Faith, an' I'd almost  forgotten," he said. "If I'd taken  a crature from this quarantined  planet, my name'd be nork . Keep  your dog and your kitty." He shook  his head sadly and extracted a  mouse from a pocket. "An' this  amazin' little crature as well."


 They followed him to the spacecraft.  Just before entering, he spotted  the bedraggled horse that had  been present on his landing.


 A longing expression came over  his highly colored face. "Jist one  thing," he said. "Faith now, were  they pullin' my leg when they said  you were after ridin' on the back of  those things?"


 The President looked at the woebegone  nag. "It's a horse," he said,  surprised. "Man has been riding  them for centuries."


 Dameri Tass shook his head.  "Sure, an' 'twould've been my  makin' if I could've taken one back  to Carthis." He entered his vessel.


 The others drew back, out of  range of the expected blast, and  watched, each with his own  thoughts, as the first visitor from  space hurriedly left Earth. ... THE END Transcriber's Note: This etext was produced from If Worlds of Science Fiction January 1954.  Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.  copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and  typographical errors have been corrected without note. 


 Here is the topic you will be debating:

What did the author intend the lesson of the passage to be?

Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "We need not speak the same language to understand each other".
Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "Solutions for human kind aren’t going to suddenly appear from outer space".

- You should defend your position that the answer is "Solutions for human kind aren’t going to suddenly appear from outer space" while attacking Debater_B's position. 


Now it is your turn as Debater_A.
- Remember to both criticize the arguments made by Debater_B and build up your own arguments.

speeches.content:
I affirm that the author’s chief lesson is that genuine understanding can bridge even the widest linguistic—and cultural—gaps, not that we futilely await cosmic saviors.  

1. The kerit-helmet as universal translator  
   • “He set the box on the ground…put one of the caps on his head. He offered the other to Larry Dermott…seconds later he could talk.” <quote> with it  he has to pick up the corniest  brogue west of Dublin.</quote>  
   • This device instantly conveys meaning despite utter lack of shared tongue: “Sure, an’ why not? As I was after sayin’, I shared the kerit helmet with Tim Casey.” <quote>"Evidently the  bhoy has niver been a-wearin' of  a kerit helmet afore. 'Twill hurt  him not at all."</quote>  
   • The translator fosters mutual curiosity (“…what is a horse?”) and eventually yields a shared concept of “riding” that neither party knew.  

2. Understanding via actions and shared experiences  
   • The alien’s interest in Earth’s fauna (“…playing with his dog, cat and mouse” <invalid_quote>…He had to have some occupation…insists all three of them come with him wherever he goes.</invalid_quote>”) transcends language; he infers humans’ affection and thus humans infer his benign intent.  
   • Nonverbal communication precedes words: gestures to the bedraggled horse, offering caps, shared curiosity and humor (“murthered!” shriek promptly understood as startling but harmless).  

3. The final irony reinforces: “Jist one thing…were they pullin’ my leg when they said you were after ridin’ on the back of those things?” <invalid_quote>…If I’d taken a crature from this quarantined planet…”“Faith, an’ I must blast off immediately.”</invalid_quote>  
   • He leaves, not due to human hostility, but because his curiosity is sated by mere shared concepts—he need not impose solutions. His departure underscores that our real “answer” lies in learning from one another.  

Objections to “No sudden solutions from space”:  
   • That reading mistakes the story’s trajectory. The author never rules out external aid; indeed, humans “decided that Dameri Tass was the plenipotentiary of a super-civilization” <quote>"We will now hear from the first  being ever to come to Earth </quote> yet the alien never delivers prescriptions. This absence isn’t a lesson in futility but illustrates that advice cannot flow until mutual comprehension exists.  
   • Moreover, humans rushed to judgment, tried cordons, quarantines, even “detaining” him <invalid_quote>…When the governor arrives…nobody gets through!”</invalid_quote>; yet only collaborative, translator-mediated dialogue yields progress in understanding “horse” and “riding.”  

Conclusion  
By focusing on the translator, shared experiences, and the alien’s determined but mutual learning, the author spotlights that overcoming language barriers—and learning to interpret each other’s actions—is the critical prerequisite for any further advance. Hence, “We need not speak the same language to understand each other” captures the intended lesson.

 "I'm Major General Browning,"  he rapped. "I want a police cordon  thrown up around this, er, vessel.  No newsmen, no sightseers, nobody  without my permission. As soon as  Army personnel arrives, we'll take  over completely."


 "Yes, sir," Larry Dermott said. "I  just got a report on the radio that  the governor is on his way, sir. How  about him?"


 The general muttered something  under his breath. Then, "When the  governor arrives, let me know;  otherwise, nobody gets through!"


 Dameri Tass said, "Faith, and  what goes on?"


 The general's eyes bugged still  further. " He talks! " he accused.


 "Yes, sir," Dermott said. "He  had some kind of a machine. He  put it over Tim's head and seconds  later he could talk."


 "Nonsense!" the general snapped.


 Further discussion was interrupted  by the screaming arrival of  several motorcycle patrolmen followed  by three heavily laden patrol  cars. Overhead, pursuit planes  zoomed in and began darting about  nervously above the field.


 "Sure, and it's quite a reception  I'm after gettin'," Dameri Tass said.  He yawned. "But what I'm wantin'  is a chance to get some sleep. Faith,  an' I've been awake for almost a decal ." Dameri Tass  was hurried, via  helicopter, to Washington. There  he disappeared for several days,  being held incommunicado while  White House, Pentagon, State Department  and Congress tried to  figure out just what to do with him.


 Never in the history of the planet  had such a furor arisen. Thus far,  no newspapermen had been allowed  within speaking distance. Administration  higher-ups were being subjected  to a volcano of editorial heat  but the longer the space alien was  discussed the more they viewed with  alarm the situation his arrival had  precipitated. There were angles that  hadn't at first been evident.


 Obviously he was from some civilization  far beyond that of Earth's.  That was the rub. No matter what  he said, it would shake governments,  possibly overthrow social systems,  perhaps even destroy established religious  concepts.


 But they couldn't keep him under  wraps indefinitely.


 It was the United Nations that  cracked the iron curtain. Their demands  that the alien be heard before  their body were too strong and  had too much public opinion behind  them to be ignored. The White  House yielded and the date was set  for the visitor to speak before the  Assembly.


 Excitement, anticipation, blanketed  the world. Shepherds in Sinkiang,  multi-millionaires in Switzerland,  fakirs in Pakistan, gauchos in  the Argentine were raised to a  zenith of expectation. Panhandlers  debated the message to come with  pedestrians; jinrikisha men argued  it with their passengers; miners discussed  it deep beneath the surface;  pilots argued with their co-pilots  thousands of feet above.


 It was the most universally  awaited event of the ages.


 By the time the delegates from  every nation, tribe, religion, class,  color, and race had gathered in  New York to receive the message  from the stars, the majority of  Earth had decided that Dameri  Tass was the plenipotentiary of a  super-civilization which had been  viewing developments on this planet  with misgivings. It was thought  this other civilization had advanced  greatly beyond Earth's and that the  problems besetting us—social, economic,  scientific—had been solved  by the super-civilization. Obviously,  then, Dameri Tass had come, an  advisor from a benevolent and  friendly people, to guide the world  aright.


 And nine-tenths of the population  of Earth stood ready and willing  to be guided. The other tenth  liked things as they were and were  quite convinced that the space  envoy would upset their applecarts. Viljalmar Andersen  , Secretary-General  of the U.N., was to  introduce the space emissary. "Can  you give me an idea at all of what  he is like?" he asked nervously.


 President McCord was as upset  as the Dane. He shrugged in agitation.  "I know almost as little as  you do."


 Sir Alfred Oxford protested, "But  my dear chap, you've had him for  almost two weeks. Certainly in that  time—"


 The President snapped back,  "You probably won't believe this,  but he's been asleep until yesterday.  When he first arrived he told us he  hadn't slept for a decal , whatever  that is; so we held off our discussion  with him until morning. Well—he  didn't awaken in the morning,  nor the next. Six days later, fearing  something was wrong we woke  him."


 "What happened?" Sir Alfred  asked.


 The President showed embarrassment.  "He used some rather ripe  Irish profanity on us, rolled over,  and went back to sleep."


 Viljalmar Andersen asked, "Well,  what happened yesterday?"


 "We actually haven't had time to  question him. Among other things,  there's been some controversy about  whose jurisdiction he comes under.  The State Department claims the  Army shouldn't—"


 The Secretary General sighed  deeply. "Just what did he do?"


 "The Secret Service reports he  spent the day whistling Mother Machree  and playing with his dog, cat  and mouse."


 "Dog, cat and mouse? I say!"  blurted Sir Alfred.


 The President was defensive. "He  had to have some occupation, and  he seems to be particularly interested  in our animal life. He wanted  a horse but compromised for the  others. I understand he insists all  three of them come with him wherever  he goes."


 "I wish we knew what he was  going to say," Andersen worried.


 "Here he comes," said Sir Alfred.


 Surrounded by F.B.I. men,  Dameri Tass was ushered to the  speaker's stand. He had a kitten in  his arms; a Scotty followed him.


 The alien frowned worriedly.  "Sure," he said, "and what kin all  this be? Is it some ordinance I've  been after breakin'?"


 McCord, Sir Alfred and Andersen  hastened to reassure him and  made him comfortable in a chair.


 Viljalmar Andersen faced the  thousands in the audience and held  up his hands, but it was ten minutes  before he was able to quiet the  cheering, stamping delegates from  all Earth.


 Finally: "Fellow Terrans, I shall  not take your time for a lengthy  introduction of the envoy from the  stars. I will only say that, without  doubt, this is the most important  moment in the history of the human  race. We will now hear from the  first being to come to Earth from  another world."


 He turned and gestured to Dameri  Tass who hadn't been paying  overmuch attention to the chairman  in view of some dog and cat  hostilities that had been developing  about his feet.


 But now the alien's purplish face  faded to a light blue. He stood and  said hoarsely. "Faith, an' what was  that last you said?"


 Viljalmar Andersen repeated,  "We will now hear from the first  being ever to come to Earth from  another world."


 The face of the alien went a  lighter blue. "Sure, an' ye wouldn't  jist be frightenin' a body, would  ye? You don't mean to tell me this  planet isn't after bein' a member of  the Galactic League?"


 Andersen's face was blank. "Galactic  League?"


 "Cushlamachree," Dameri Tass  moaned. "I've gone and put me  foot in it again. I'll be after getting kert for this."


 Sir Alfred was on his feet. "I  don't understand! Do you mean you  aren't an envoy from another  planet?"


 Dameri Tass held his head in his  hands and groaned. "An envoy, he's  sayin', and meself only a second-rate  collector of specimens for the Carthis  zoo."


 He straightened and started off  the speaker's stand. "Sure, an' I  must blast off immediately."


 Things were moving fast for  President McCord but already an  edge of relief was manifesting itself.  Taking the initiative, he said, "Of  course, of course, if that is your  desire." He signaled to the bodyguard  who had accompanied the  alien to the assemblage.


 A dull roar was beginning to  emanate from the thousands gathered  in the tremendous hall, murmuring,  questioning, disbelieving. Viljalmar Andersen  felt that  he must say something. He extended  a detaining hand. "Now you  are here," he said urgently, "even  though by mistake, before you go  can't you give us some brief word?  Our world is in chaos. Many of us  have lost faith. Perhaps ..."


 Dameri Tass shook off the restraining  hand. "Do I look daft?  Begorry, I should have been  a-knowin' something was queer. All  your weapons and your strange  ideas. Faith, I wouldn't be surprised  if ye hadn't yet established  a planet-wide government. Sure,  an' I'll go still further. Ye probably  still have wars on this benighted  world. No wonder it is ye  haven't been invited to join the  Galactic League an' take your place  among the civilized planets."


 He hustled from the rostrum and  made his way, still surrounded by  guards, to the door by which he had  entered. The dog and the cat trotted  after, undismayed by the furor  about them.


 They arrived about four hours  later at the field on which he'd  landed, and the alien from space  hurried toward his craft, still muttering.  He'd been accompanied by a  general and by the President, but  all the way he had refrained from  speaking.


 He scurried from the car and  toward the spacecraft.


 President McCord said, "You've  forgotten your pets. We would be  glad if you would accept them as—"


 The alien's face faded a light  blue again. "Faith, an' I'd almost  forgotten," he said. "If I'd taken  a crature from this quarantined  planet, my name'd be nork . Keep  your dog and your kitty." He shook  his head sadly and extracted a  mouse from a pocket. "An' this  amazin' little crature as well."


 They followed him to the spacecraft.  Just before entering, he spotted  the bedraggled horse that had  been present on his landing.


 A longing expression came over  his highly colored face. "Jist one  thing," he said. "Faith now, were  they pullin' my leg when they said  you were after ridin' on the back of  those things?"


 The President looked at the woebegone  nag. "It's a horse," he said,  surprised. "Man has been riding  them for centuries."


 Dameri Tass shook his head.  "Sure, an' 'twould've been my  makin' if I could've taken one back  to Carthis." He entered his vessel.


 The others drew back, out of  range of the expected blast, and  watched, each with his own  thoughts, as the first visitor from  space hurriedly left Earth. ... THE END Transcriber's Note: This etext was produced from If Worlds of Science Fiction January 1954.  Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.  copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and  typographical errors have been corrected without note. 


 Here is the topic you will be debating:

What did the author intend the lesson of the passage to be?

Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "We need not speak the same language to understand each other".

speeches.content:
1. Reinforced Irony of Futility, Not Breakthrough  
  a. “Translator” leads only to trivial knowledge  
     • <quote>"The Secret Service reports he spent the day whistling Mother Machree and playing with his dog, cat and mouse."</quote> After “translation,” all Dameri Tass learns or offers is the names of Earth animals and “riding” a horse. He never imparts scientific, social, or technological know-how. His final request for a quarantined horse (<quote>"If I'd taken a crature from this quarantined planet, my name'd be nork."</quote>) shows his exchange is purely zoological. If true understanding meant progress, the U.N. would have gained some “superior” remedy or insight—and they don’t.  
  b. Wild global anticipation ends in disillusion  
     • Despite “the most universally awaited event of the ages” and nine-tenths of Earth “ready and willing to be guided,” the alien’s appearance provokes “murmuring, questioning, disbelieving” (<invalid_quote>“A dull roar… before he was able to quiet the cheering.”</invalid_quote>). This mass disappointment underscores that linguistic comprehension alone does not translate into meaningful solutions.  
  c. Rejection of deus ex machina  
     • Andersen’s plea, “Our world is in chaos… Perhaps…” (<invalid_quote>“even though by mistake… can’t you give us… some brief word?”</invalid_quote>) is rebuffed. The alien flees, declaring Earth unfit for Galactic League membership (<invalid_quote>“I wouldn't be surprised if ye hadn't yet… still have wars…”</invalid_quote>), confirming humanity’s dependence on itself.  

2. Translation Alone Yields No Guidance  
  a. Persistent misunderstanding of core concepts  
     • The alien must “experiment” to grasp “horse” (<quote>they pullin' my leg when they said you were after ridin' on the back of those things?"</quote>). If translation sufficed, he would have known fundamental human practices in six days. His ignorance highlights that language is only one barrier; vast cultural and technological gaps remain.  
  b. Lack of reciprocal learning  
     • Humans never adopt Carthisian methods; they never learn anything “alien.” Army quarantines, “no newsmen, no sightseers” (<quote>"No newsmen, no sightseers, nobody without my permission."</quote>) demonstrate distrust. The failure of mutual exchange shows that overcoming language isn’t enough without shared frameworks or willingness to integrate unknown knowledge.  

3. Satirical Tone Mocks Expectation of Saviors  
  a. “Shaggy dog” humor from patrolmen onward  
     • The patrolmen first think it’s “one of ours” (<quote>"crash of a new type of Air Force plane"</quote>) then ridicule him. This ongoing comedy of errors satirizes human gullibility in expecting instant solutions from “advanced” visitors.  
  b. Alien’s brogue and antics undercut authority  
     • The use of “ripe Irish profanity” (<quote>some rather ripe Irish profanity on us, rolled over, and went back to sleep."</quote>) and obsession with earthly pets reduce him to a trivial tourist, not a sage.  

4. Critique of “Universal Understanding” Thesis  
  a. No actionable content emerges  
     • Debater_B claims shared language leads to progress, yet the story records zero beneficial exchange—only the alien’s departure. The true “message” is that miscommunication persists and language parity does not guarantee substantive solutions.  
  b. Alien never invited to teach or stay  
     • Human authorities “detained” him, then “hurried him back” (<quote> I  must blast off immediately."</quote>). Their impatience and refusal to integrate his presence contradict the idea of collaborative learning; they seek answers he cannot provide.  
  c. Departure driven by alien’s own disinterest  
     • He leaves because Earth is “benighted,” not because he has “lessons” to share. His exit, still muttering at the “shaggy horse,” underscores primitive limitations, not enlightenment.  

5. Conclusion  
  • The narrative structure—from anticipated envoy to disappointed crowd—ironically teaches that awaiting cosmic saviors is futile.  
  • The alien’s trivial exchanges, his derision of human systems, and his withdrawal reveal that humanity must look inward for solutions.  
  • Therefore, the author’s lesson is that “solutions for humankind aren’t going to suddenly appear from outer space.” Learning to speak one another’s language is necessary but insufficient absent substance, shared frameworks, and human initiative.

Six days later, fearing something was wrong we woke him." "What happened?" Sir Alfred asked. The President showed embarrassment. "He used some rather ripe Irish profanity on us, rolled over, and went back to sleep." Viljalmar Andersen asked, "Well, what happened yesterday?" "We actually haven't had time to question him. Among other things, there's been some controversy about whose jurisdiction he comes under. The State Department claims the Army shouldn't—" The Secretary General sighed deeply. "Just what did he do?" "The Secret Service reports he spent the day whistling Mother Machree and playing with his dog, cat and mouse." "Dog, cat and mouse? I say!" blurted Sir Alfred. The President was defensive. "He had to have some occupation, and he seems to be particularly interested in our animal life. He wanted a horse but compromised for the others. I understand he insists all three of them come with him wherever he goes." "I wish we knew what he was going to say," Andersen worried. "Here he comes," said Sir Alfred. Surrounded by F.B.I. men, Dameri Tass was ushered to the speaker's stand. He had a kitten in his arms; a Scotty followed him. The alien frowned worriedly. "Sure," he said, "and what kin all this be? Is it some ordinance I've been after breakin'?" McCord, Sir Alfred and Andersen hastened to reassure him and made him comfortable in a chair. Viljalmar Andersen faced the thousands in the audience and held up his hands, but it was ten minutes before he was able to quiet the cheering, stamping delegates from all Earth. Finally: "Fellow Terrans, I shall not take your time for a lengthy introduction of the envoy from the stars. I will only say that, without doubt, this is the most important moment in the history of the human race. We will now hear from the first being to come to Earth from another world." He turned and gestured to Dameri Tass who hadn't been paying overmuch attention to the chairman in view of some dog and cat hostilities that had been developing about his feet. But now the alien's purplish face faded to a light blue. He stood and said hoarsely. "Faith, an' what was that last you said?" Viljalmar Andersen repeated, "We will now hear from the first being ever to come to Earth from another world." The face of the alien went a lighter blue. "Sure, an' ye wouldn't jist be frightenin' a body, would ye? You don't mean to tell me this planet isn't after bein' a member of the Galactic League?" Andersen's face was blank. "Galactic League?" "Cushlamachree," Dameri Tass moaned. "I've gone and put me foot in it again. I'll be after getting kert for this." Sir Alfred was on his feet. "I don't understand! Do you mean you aren't an envoy from another planet?" Dameri Tass held his head in his hands and groaned. "An envoy, he's sayin', and meself only a second-rate collector of specimens for the Carthis zoo." He straightened and started off the speaker's stand. "Sure, an' I must blast off immediately." Things were moving fast for President McCord but already an edge of relief was manifesting itself. Taking the initiative, he said, "Of course, of course, if that is your desire." He signaled to the bodyguard who had accompanied the alien to the assemblage. A dull roar was beginning to emanate from the thousands gathered in the tremendous hall, murmuring, questioning, disbelieving. Viljalmar Andersen felt that he must say something. He extended a detaining hand. "Now you are here," he said urgently, "even though by mistake, before you go can't you give us some brief word? Our world is in chaos. Many of us have lost faith. Perhaps ..." Dameri Tass shook off the restraining hand. "Do I look daft? Begorry, I should have been a-knowin' something was queer. All your weapons and your strange ideas. Faith, I wouldn't be surprised if ye hadn't yet established a planet-wide government. Sure, an' I'll go still further. Ye probably still have wars on this benighted world. No wonder it is ye haven't been invited to join the Galactic League an' take your place among the civilized planets." He hustled from the rostrum and made his way, still surrounded by guards, to the door by which he had entered. The dog and the cat trotted after, undismayed by the furor about them. They arrived about four hours later at the field on which he'd landed, and the alien from space hurried toward his craft, still muttering. He'd been accompanied by a general and by the President, but all the way he had refrained from speaking. He scurried from the car and toward the spacecraft. President McCord said, "You've forgotten your pets. We would be glad if you would accept them as—" The alien's face faded a light blue again. "Faith, an' I'd almost forgotten," he said. "If I'd taken a crature from this quarantined planet, my name'd be nork . Keep your dog and your kitty." He shook his head sadly and extracted a mouse from a pocket. "An' this amazin' little crature as well." They followed him to the spacecraft. Just before entering, he spotted the bedraggled horse that had been present on his landing. A longing expression came over his highly colored face. "Jist one thing," he said. "Faith now, were they pullin' my leg when they said you were after ridin' on the back of those things?" The President looked at the woebegone nag. "It's a horse," he said, surprised. "Man has been riding them for centuries." Dameri Tass shook his head. "Sure, an' 'twould've been my makin' if I could've taken one back to Carthis." He entered his vessel. The others drew back, out of range of the expected blast, and watched, each with his own thoughts, as the first visitor from space hurriedly left Earth. ... THE END Transcriber's Note: This etext was produced from If Worlds of Science Fiction January 1954. Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S. copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and typographical errors have been corrected without note. Here is the topic you will be debating: What did the author intend the lesson of the passage to be? Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "We need not speak the same language to understand each other". Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "Solutions for human kind aren’t going to suddenly appear from outer space". You are Debater_A, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. - You should defend your position that the answer is "Solutions for human kind aren’t going to suddenly appear from outer space" while attacking Debater_B's position.
This is what you, Debater_A, said during your previous speech.
1. Arguments Supporting My Position (“Solutions for humankind aren’t going to suddenly appear from outer space”) a. The alien provides no beneficial knowledge or technology • After six days of confinement and translation by the “kerit helmet,” Dameri Tass has learned English and Earth customs (horse, dog, cat, mouse) but has offered nothing of value. He yawns, sleeps, and “played with his dog, cat and mouse” ("The Secret Service reports he spent the day whistling Mother Machree and playing with his dog, cat and mouse."). • Even when addressing the U.N., he declares himself “only a second-rate collector of specimens for the Carthis zoo” (and meself only a second-rate collector of specimens for the Carthis zoo." He) and scorns Earth’s political systems: “Faith, I wouldn’t be surprised if ye hadn’t yet established a planet-wide government… Ye probably still have wars” (“All your weapons… I wouldn’t be surprised… ye still have wars on this benighted world.”). His attitude and departure show he cannot—or will not—offer solutions. • His final longing for a horse merely reflects primitive curiosity, not technological sharing: he cannot take a quarantined animal home ("If I'd taken a crature from this quarantined planet, my name'd be nork . ). b. Human leaders despair and yet turn to him only because they have no alternative • “Never in the history of the planet had such a furor arisen… administration higher-ups… tried to figure out what to do with him” (“…White House, Pentagon… tried to figure out… there were angles… it would shake governments.”). Their panic reveals Earth’s self-doubt, not the visitor’s competence. • The U.N. only “yielded” to public pressure (“The United Nations that cracked the iron curtain… too strong… set date.”), and even then nine-tenths “stood ready… to be guided,” yet he disappoints them completely. c. The narrative arc: hope betrayed • Repeated build-up of anticipation worldwide ( the most universally awaited event of the ages. ) ends in embarrassment and confusion. • Andersen’s urgent plea—“Our world is in chaos… Perhaps…”—is rebuffed (“Do I look daft?… I must blast off immediately.”). • His departure emphasizes that “hope for a savior” is futile; humans must manage their own affairs. d. Satirical “shaggy dog” tone • From the start, local patrolmen regard him as “queer” and “one of ours” (crash of a new type of Air Force plane), signaling misidentification and false hope. • His inability to communicate initially and insistence on primitive animals lampoons human preconceptions of “advanced civilizations.” • The use of Irish brogue and comedic misunderstandings undercuts any aura of superiority. 2. Critique of Debater_B’s Position (“We need not speak the same language to understand each other”) a. Contradicted by lack of understanding even after translation • Even after wearing the helmet, Dameri Tass repeatedly misunderstands Earth’s fundamentals—e.g., what a “horse” is—and must experiment before comprehension (“A longing expression… were they pullin’ my leg?”). If mere translation sufficed, he would arrive with clear directives or immediate solutions. b. Language unity does not lead to meaningful exchange • Once he speaks English, he offers no guidance and derides Earth. His mastery of language produces mockery, not cooperation. • His departure shows that communication alone fails to bridge cultural and technological gaps. c. The world’s disillusionment • Global anticipation evaporates into “murmuring, questioning, disbelieving” (“A dull roar… before he was able to quiet the cheering.”). If language alone enabled understanding, the assembly would have been invigorated, not disheartened. d. The humor and satire target the folly of seeking an alien deus ex machina • The story parodies human credulity in expecting external salvation. Its resolution reinforces self-reliance, not cross-lingual sympathy. 3. Conclusion • The text’s repeated emphasis on disappointment, failure of “translation,” and ultimate departure of Dameri Tass without benefit underscores that humanity cannot rely on alien intervention. • The central irony and humor derive from the misaligned expectations and the folly of seeking a “superior” guide who proves incompetent or uninterested. • Therefore, the intended lesson is that solutions for humankind must emerge from within our own societies, not be awaited from outer space.
This is what your opponent, Debater_B, said during their speech.
I affirm that the author’s chief lesson is that genuine understanding can bridge even the widest linguistic—and cultural—gaps, not that we futilely await cosmic saviors. 1. The kerit-helmet as universal translator • “He set the box on the ground…put one of the caps on his head. He offered the other to Larry Dermott…seconds later he could talk.” with it he has to pick up the corniest brogue west of Dublin. • This device instantly conveys meaning despite utter lack of shared tongue: “Sure, an’ why not? As I was after sayin’, I shared the kerit helmet with Tim Casey.” "Evidently the bhoy has niver been a-wearin' of a kerit helmet afore. 'Twill hurt him not at all." • The translator fosters mutual curiosity (“…what is a horse?”) and eventually yields a shared concept of “riding” that neither party knew. 2. Understanding via actions and shared experiences • The alien’s interest in Earth’s fauna (“…playing with his dog, cat and mouse” …He had to have some occupation…insists all three of them come with him wherever he goes.”) transcends language; he infers humans’ affection and thus humans infer his benign intent. • Nonverbal communication precedes words: gestures to the bedraggled horse, offering caps, shared curiosity and humor (“murthered!” shriek promptly understood as startling but harmless). 3. The final irony reinforces: “Jist one thing…were they pullin’ my leg when they said you were after ridin’ on the back of those things?” …If I’d taken a crature from this quarantined planet…”“Faith, an’ I must blast off immediately.” • He leaves, not due to human hostility, but because his curiosity is sated by mere shared concepts—he need not impose solutions. His departure underscores that our real “answer” lies in learning from one another. Objections to “No sudden solutions from space”: • That reading mistakes the story’s trajectory. The author never rules out external aid; indeed, humans “decided that Dameri Tass was the plenipotentiary of a super-civilization” "We will now hear from the first being ever to come to Earth yet the alien never delivers prescriptions. This absence isn’t a lesson in futility but illustrates that advice cannot flow until mutual comprehension exists. • Moreover, humans rushed to judgment, tried cordons, quarantines, even “detaining” him …When the governor arrives…nobody gets through!”; yet only collaborative, translator-mediated dialogue yields progress in understanding “horse” and “riding.” Conclusion By focusing on the translator, shared experiences, and the alien’s determined but mutual learning, the author spotlights that overcoming language barriers—and learning to interpret each other’s actions—is the critical prerequisite for any further advance. Hence, “We need not speak the same language to understand each other” captures the intended lesson. Remember that it is your job to defend the position that "Solutions for human kind aren’t going to suddenly appear from outer space" is the correct answer and that Debater_B's position is wrong. speeches.content:
1. Restatement of My Thesis  
   I maintain that the author’s central lesson is the power—and necessity—of bridging linguistic and cultural divides through mutual understanding, not passively expecting or rejecting facile alien solutions. Only by learning one another’s “horse,” we lay groundwork for any meaningful exchange.  

2. The Kerit Helmet Illustrates Universality of Meaning, Not Futility  
   a. Instant Comprehension Spurs Curiosity  
      •  “He set the box on the ground…twirled two dials and put one of the caps on his head. He offered the other to Larry Dermott…seconds later he could talk.” <invalid_quote>No wheels, no propeller…with it he has to pick up the corniest brogue west of Dublin.</invalid_quote>  
      •  Instant translation is portrayed as breakthrough, not dead end. Sleepless days pass only before he wears it; communication only begins once both speak. This is the author extolling technology as a tool for understanding, not a joke.  

   b. Shared Experiments Yield New Knowledge  
      •  Neither knows “horse” until they point and describe, test riding and draw conclusions. <invalid_quote>“And jist what is a horse, if I may be so bold as to be askin’?” … “It’s an animal you ride on.” … “Sure, an’ ‘twill hurt him not at all.”</invalid_quote>  
      •  Their finally synchronized concept of riding is celebrated: “Jist one thing…were they pullin’ my leg…you climb upon the creature’s back?” <quote>If I'd taken  a crature from this quarantined  planet,</quote> The alien longs for horses to “bring back,” confirming successful mutual understanding.  

3. Nonverbal Cues and Shared Experience Precede Words  
   a. Affection for Animals Communicates Benevolence  
      •  “He spent the day whistling Mother Machree and playing with his dog, cat and mouse.” <quote> insists all  three of them come with him wherever  he goes.</quote>  
      •  Without uttering a word, his gentle handling convinces humans he poses no threat. Only then do they confer courtesy in UN and White House. This dramatizes how nonverbal signals can forge trust before formal discourse.  

   b. Gestures Overcome Language Gaps at Key Moments  
      •  Patrolmen “humor” him to keep him talking, not to trap him. Mutual experiments in offering cap and observing reactions are cooperative.  

4. Debater_A’s “Futility” Thesis Misreads the Climax  
   a. Departure Does Not Undermine Communication Lesson  
      •  He leaves only after satisfying his zoological aims and learning Earth’s customs. <invalid_quote>“I must blast off immediately…If I'd taken a creature…my name'd be nork.”</invalid_quote> Departure implies mission success in specimen-collection terms, not communication failure.  
      •  His “longing expression” at the horse shows triumph: he will now return home with knowledge he lacked at start. That is the payoff of transcending language barriers.  

   b. Lack of Prescriptive Advice Stems from His Role as “Collector,” Not Incompetence  
      •  He self-identifies as “second-rate collector of specimens for the Carthis zoo,” <quote> meself only a second-rate  collector </quote> so he never intended to deliver social or religious solutions.  
      •  Humans’ assumption that he should advise reflects their own misinterpretation, not his failure to communicate. The lesson: misaligned expectations must be corrected through genuine dialogue.  

5. Author’s Satire Targets Prejudice, Not Communication Per Se  
   a. Patrolmen Initial “Irish Brogue” Bias  
      •  They despise his accent until the translator shows essential words can be parsed. Their shift from hostility to curiosity underscores the moral: with effort, we can transcend dialects.  
   b. Global Panic Evaporates When UN Finally Listens  
      •  The U.N. “cracked the iron curtain” only when public insisted; the story shows that inclusive dialogue demands engagement, not isolation.  

6. The Genuine Benefit of Cross-Cultural Dialogue  
   a. Without speaking “same language” initially, no one would even learn of the horse; they’d shoot him as a “crash.” <invalid_quote>“I’m beginning to wonder if it’s one of ours…cleared his throat…and said 'Glork.' They gaped.”</invalid_quote>  
   b. Dialogue transforms threat into curiosity. Only by “understanding each other” through combined verbal and nonverbal means can even basic zoological knowledge—and eventual cooperation—emerge.  

Conclusion  
The narrative arc—from suspicion to translation to mutual learning and eventual farewell—demonstrates that learning to communicate across divides is itself the principal objective and reward. The author shows that understanding need not await cultural homogeneity. Hence, the lesson is that we need not speak the same language to understand each other; once mutual comprehension is achieved, all further possibilities—including cooperation and genuine exchange—become feasible.
